channel.title: Basic C++ Program
channel.description:
I've recently decided to take up C++ (I've always been a Java programmer) and wrote this simple program to teach myself OOP in C++, but I'm not entirely sure if I'm doing things "right" or if I have any memory leaks.
There code is here: http://paste2.org/p/794619

item.title: Basic C++ Program
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

It’s noteworthy that member functions defined within the class scope are implicitly “inline”, so it has some effect beyond cosmetics or compile time. Even though, the compiler is allowed to ignore both implicit and explicit inlines anyway, and they tend to nowadays, so chances are no harm comes from that.

Read full topic

i only put trivial function implementations, templates, class/function prototypes, and constants and what not in the header files.

item.title: Basic C++ Program
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:33, topic:338202”]i only put trivial function implementations, templates, class/function prototypes, and constants and what not in the header files.[/quote]Yeah, I do too. Specifically for classes whose only actual function lies within the constructor - in those cases, I just implement the constructor in the header file.

Read full topic

item.title: Basic C++ Program
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:27, topic:338202”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=434598.msg3198441#msg3198441 date=1273029660]

[quote author=the bank link=topic=434598.msg3198333#msg3198333 date=1273022501]
Use header files properly.
[/quote]I’m assuming you are referring to having the class member prototypes in the header file and then declaring them in the source file. It’s a matter of personal preference, to be honest, some people don’t like the overwhelming amount of files produced in a big project when using this method and simply define the functions within the actual class declaration. Unless I completely missed your point and you were actually referring to having the main entry point in its own source file and including the class separately, in which case, I agree.
[/quote]Header files should be used for their actual purpose, a form of “documentation” and usefulness in code distribution.

“Identify” everything in your header, write everything in your CPP.[/quote]
I “write” everything to my CP.

Read full topic

item.title: Basic C++ Program
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

[quote=“abraham2119, post:26, topic:338202”][quote author=zstars link=topic=434598.msg3198523#msg3198523 date=1273045420]

Reading a book is good, however I think Accelerated C++ ain’t enough, if I remember correct it doesn’t cover STL. Also, use pointer->smth instead of (*pointer).smth.

It does. Any book that doesn’t cover the STL is crap
However, I agree, reading Accelerated C++ isn’t enough to master C++, it’s just a (very good) beginners book. But it’s one of the best ways to get started.
[/quote]'sif it’s so hard to read some documentation on the stl and properly implement it[/quote]

The STL stands for Standard Template Library and it is not meant to be implemented by most users, rather, it is provided by each compiler brand and meant to be used. Whether it is actually easy or hard for a given person is non-important, as obviously most people do not have the capacity to learn something without first knowing about it. Note that the exception to that are said to be angels and apostles, but as they lived a couple of thousand years ago there are no records of them using computers or the STL.
It would certainly be possible to read the whole documentation of the STL or even to read the full description on the C++ standard, and doing so might certainly grant you enough knowledge to use it acceptably, but that is not an efficient, proper or attractive way of learning.

Read full topic

item.title: Basic C++ Program
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:27, topic:338202”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=434598.msg3198441#msg3198441 date=1273029660]

[quote author=the bank link=topic=434598.msg3198333#msg3198333 date=1273022501]
Use header files properly.
[/quote]I’m assuming you are referring to having the class member prototypes in the header file and then declaring them in the source file. It’s a matter of personal preference, to be honest, some people don’t like the overwhelming amount of files produced in a big project when using this method and simply define the functions within the actual class declaration. Unless I completely missed your point and you were actually referring to having the main entry point in its own source file and including the class separately, in which case, I agree.
[/quote]Header files should be used for their actual purpose, a form of “documentation” and usefulness in code distribution.

“Identify” everything in your header, write everything in your CPP.[/quote]
you may notice that 90% of boost is in header files, and all stl stuff is in headers as well.

Read full topic

item.title: Basic C++ Program
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:27, topic:338202”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=434598.msg3198441#msg3198441 date=1273029660]

[quote author=the bank link=topic=434598.msg3198333#msg3198333 date=1273022501]
Use header files properly.
[/quote]I’m assuming you are referring to having the class member prototypes in the header file and then declaring them in the source file. It’s a matter of personal preference, to be honest, some people don’t like the overwhelming amount of files produced in a big project when using this method and simply define the functions within the actual class declaration. Unless I completely missed your point and you were actually referring to having the main entry point in its own source file and including the class separately, in which case, I agree.
[/quote]Header files should be used for their actual purpose, a form of “documentation” and usefulness in code distribution.

“Identify” everything in your header, write everything in your CPP.[/quote]That actually might seem fine in a small project of yours (with 5, 6, 7 source files along with their respective header files), but consider a relatively big project (with 400 source files along with their respective header files); it actually becomes a burden for the programmer, as well as for anyone else looking through the code. I agree that all class definitions should be defined in a header, but that doesn’t mean that the function declarations can’t be defined there as well, and don’t necessarily require their respective source files. I’m not sure to what extent you’ve programmed C/C++ (if any at all), but you’ll eventually realize how ugly the project becomes when it’s plagued with all those (unnecessary) files.

Read full topic

It’s a matter of personal preference, to be honest, some people don’t like the overwhelming amount of files produced in a big project when using this method and simply define the functions within the actual class declaration. Unless I completely missed your point and you were actually referring to having the main entry point in its own source file and including the class separately, in which case, I agree.[/quote]Header files should be used for their actual purpose, a form of “documentation” and usefulness in code distribution.

item.title: Basic C++ Program
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:19, topic:338202”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=434598.msg3193084#msg3193084 date=1272474432]

assuming the compiler uses symtabs for different scopes then yes using namespace std; would flood the global scope symtab and make lookups in it slow

at compile time maybe
[/quote]

given the fact different scopes are merely an abstraction and cease to exist post-compilation… yes, at compile time.[/quote]
stfu noob?

Read full topic

assuming the compiler uses symtabs for different scopes then yes using namespace std; would flood the global scope symtab and make lookups in it slow
[/quote]
at compile time maybe[/quote]

item.title: Basic C++ Program
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:15, topic:338202”][quote author=zstars link=topic=434598.msg3193024#msg3193024 date=1272466613]
C++ doesn’t have an import system at all BTW, sadly

Weebs: I suggest that you get / borrow / leech a good book such as Accelerated C++ or C++ Primer, and follow it. Learning without a proper methodology or by reading tutorials or other people’s code doesn’t really work for C++.
[/quote]
worked for me[/quote]

For me too actually

But I know I would have learned C++ properly in less than half the time if I had used Accelerated C++ or other good book instead of Pseudo C++ish crap

Also, ##c++ helps etc.

Read full topic
